sen.j: アリス・メイベル・ベーコン（Alice Mabel Bacon、1858年～1918年5月1日）は、アメリカ合衆国人女性教育者。
sen.e: Alice Mabel Bacon (1858 - May 1, 1918) is an American female educator.

sen.e: Her father is Leonard Bacon, a clergyman of New Haven, Connecticut, and mother is Catharine.

sen.j: キャサリンは後妻で、アリスは14人兄弟の末娘であった。
sen.e: Catharine was the second wife and Alice was the youngest girl of 14 children.

sen.j: 父・レオナルドは牧師のほかイェール大学神学校の教師も勤め、南北戦争の時、いち早く奴隷制に反対する論陣を張るなど、人望が厚く地元の名士であった。
sen.e: Her father Leonard, served as not only a clergyman but also a teacher at Yale Divinity School, was a respected local prominent figure, argued against slavery during the Civil War.

sen.j: 1872年、日本から来た女子留学生の下宿先を探していた森有礼の申し出に応じて山川捨松を引き取ったのは日本政府から支払われる多額の謝礼が目当てであったといわれる。
sen.e: It is said that they acceded Arinori MORI's offer when Arinori was looking for boarding houses for overseas female students from Japan, and took in Sutematsu YAMAKAWA, because of the large amount of the remuneration from the Japanese government.

sen.e: However, the Bacons treated Sutematsu as their own daughter, and Sutematsu particularly spent time with Alice, who was similar in age, as if they were real sisters.

sen.e: Although, Alice graduated from Hillhouse High School, a local high school, she gave up going to college due to their financial situation.

sen.e: However, in 1881, she passed the certificate exam for the bachelor degree of Harvard University, and in 1883, she began teaching at Hampton Institute.

sen.e: In 1884, she was invited to Japan by Sutematsu Oyama and Umeko TSUDA as an English teacher at Kazoku Jogakko (girls' school for Kazoku new nobility) (later the Gakushuin School Corporation).

sen.j: 来日中の1年間の手紙をまとめたものを1894年『日本の内側』（日本語訳題『華族女学校教師が見た明治日本の内側』）として出版し反響を呼ぶ。
sen.e: In 1894, She compiled a whole book of her letters she wrote in the year when she was in Japan, published as "A Japanese Interior" (Japanese title" Inside of the Meiji Japan through the eyes of a teacher of Kazoku Jogakko"), and it called forth an echo.

In 1894, She compiled her letters she had written during staying in Japan for one year and published the book titled "A Japanese Interior" (Japanese title was "Kazoku-jogakko-kyoshi ga mita Meiji Nihon no Uchigawa" [A Interior of Japan of the Meiji period that a teacher of Kazoku Jogakko had seen]); and it produced a sensation.

sen.j: 帰国後はハンプトン師範学校校長となっていたが、1900年4月、大山捨松と津田梅子の再度の招聘により東京女子師範学校と女子英学塾（後の津田塾大学）の英語教師として赴任、1902年4月に任期満了で帰国するまで貢献した。
sen.e: Although, she had been assigned to the principal of Hampton Institute after returning home, in 1900, she was once again invited to Japan by Sutematsu OYAMA and Umeko TSUDA, worked and made a contribution there as an English teacher of Tokyo Joshi Shihan Gakko (Tokyo Women's Normal School) and the Women's Institute for English Studies (later Tsuda College) until she left Japan in April 1902.

After returning to America, she became principal of Hampton Institute, however, in April of 1900 she was once again invited to Japan by Sutematsu OYAMA and Umeko TSUDA, and served Tokyo Joshi Shihan-gakko (Tokyo Teacher's School for Women) and Joshi Eigaku Juku (Women's English School, present Tsudajuku Collage) as an English teacher until her term of office expired and she left Japan in April of 1902.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ、訳語選択ミスがあります。女子英学塾はWomen's English School、津田塾大学ホームページに従います。

Especially at Joshi Eigaku Juku, she rendered many services as she had worked without salary and even paid the rents for the head of the school, Umeko.

sen.j: 帰国後も教育に身を捧げ、一生独身であった。
sen.e: She was involved only in education even after coming back, and she stayed single all her life.

sen.j: 先述した『日本の内側』、それ以前に著した『日本の女性』（日本語訳題『明治日本の女たち』）は明治時代の日本の女性事情を偏見無く書いた史料として貴重であり、ルース・ベネディクトが『菊と刀』を執筆するときに参考文献とした。
sen.e: "A Japanese Interior," mentioned earlier and "Japanese Girls and Women (Japanese translation "Japanese Girls and Women in the Meiji Period")," written later on by Alice are the important historical souces that explain the situation of Japanese women in the Meiji period without prejudice; Ruth Benedict used it as reference literature to write "The Chrysanthemum and the Sword."

Her books "A Japanese Interior" mentioned above and "Japanese Girls and Women" (Japanese title was "Meiji Nihon no Onna-tachi" [Japanese Girls and Women of the Meiji Period]) written before "A Japanese Interior" are important historical materials that describe Japanese women of the Meiji period without prejudice; and Ruth Benedict referred to it to write "The Chrysanthemum and the Sword."

sen.j: ちなみに『日本の女性』の前書きには「生涯の友人・大山捨松に捧げる」という一文が添えられ、捨松とは死ぬ直前まで文通を交わしていた。
sen.e: There was a sentence added which said ‛To my companion for eternity, Sutematsu Oyama' in the foreword of the book,"A Japanese Interior," and Alice exchanged letters with Sutematsu until shortly before Alice's death.

sen.e: In that connection, in the preface of "Japanese Girls and Women," she had written this sentence ‛to my lifelong friend, Sutematsu Oyama' and she had been exchanging letters with Sutematsu until just before she died.
